BODY.BHEAD: University of Michigan Image Services Characterization

DIV1.P: Image Services, part of the Digital Library Production Service at the University of Michigan, was established to federate digital image collections online for the purpose of campus and broader public access. Participation in the Museum Educational Site Licensing Project and related campus activities highlighted the existing diversity among curatorial practices and management systems, in museums, libraries, visual resources departments, and commercial distributors. While there is clearly much to be gained through standardization, we feel that the diversity exists for logical, as well as historical, reasons (ranging from curatorial opinion to technological infrastructure) and that it should be supported at the same time that we encourage standardized practices.

Image Services has been very successful in creating a service for the campus that enables and facilitates online access to image collections. The term "collections" is used loosely and includes faculty databases as well as museum, archive, library, visual resources, and commercial databases. Organizationally within the University Library, Image Services leverages the Library's commitment to providing online access to image content, and absorbs the marginal costs of providing the same services to the broader campus. Technically, Image Services has minimized the requirements for submitting data, and developed generalized mechanisms for processing data that make deployment online simple. With no costs and minimal technical requirements for the content provider, it is often just a matter of handing data off to Image Services.

It is worth emphasizing that Image Services only provides online access services for image collections. The libraries, museums, etc. that provide content use a variety of database systems to manage their data (e.g., FileMaker Pro, Oracle, Excel). Periodically, content providers transfer the latest version of their entire database to Image Services for updating online. Only entire databases are updated, and there is no provision for the update of individual records. This approach has pros and cons.

DIV2.P: Federated Content: Content providers are not only on campus, but from other institutions and commercial entities. All content is integrated into a common system for access.

Core Categories: Collection specific database fields can easily be mapped to one or more core category sets, such as Dublin Core and VRA Core. This increases compatibility and enhances searchablity among similar collections. All collections are searchable together in the Image Services access system. At the same time, the collections are searchable independently by the unique attributes of each.
Optimized for Access: The Image Services system is optimized to provide access, without the overhead of a management system. Relational data structures are flattened for efficiency.
Independent Management: Departments can choose management systems appropriate to needs and available resources.

Reliable Public Access: The majority of the content providers have extremely limited resources for providing reliable public access. Image Services has robust servers, backed up, constantly monitored, and with advanced baseline services such as institutional login.
Currency Lag: Since collections are updated periodically and in their entirety, the version in Image Services is typically not as current as the version for management.
No Editing: Database records cannot be edited through the Image Services system.
